label: W2 continuity bound without offset (for $k\ge 2$)
title: W2 continuity bound without offset (for $k\ge 2$)
nl_statement: The 2-Wasserstein metric on the output space (quotient) provides a continuity bound removing additive offsets from independent randomness.

hypotheses.text: The measures $\mu$ and $\nu$ are on $\overline{\Sigma}_N$, the $N$-particle quotient state space with the displacement metric $\overline d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}$.

conclusion.text: The 2-Wasserstein metric $W_2^2(\mu,\nu)$ is defined as the infimum of the integral of the squared displacement metric over all couplings $\pi$ between $\mu$ and $\nu$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The space $(\overline{\Sigma}_N, \overline d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}})$ is a metric space suitable for defining the Wasserstein distance.
The preceding context defined $\overline{\Sigma}_N$ and $\overline d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}$.

nl_statement: The stagewise bounds from Section 17.2.4, when repeated under synchronous coupling, maintain linear and sub-linear dependencies on $V_{\text{in}}=d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)^2$, but eliminate additive offsets from independent randomness. Specifically, when $\mathcal{S}_1=\mathcal{S}_2$, the bound holds with no constant term.

hypotheses.text: The coefficients $C_{\Psi,L}, C_{\Psi,H}$ are exactly those defined in 17.2.4.1.

conclusion.text: The stagewise bounds from Section 17.2.4 hold under synchronous coupling, yielding the stated bound with no constant term when $\mathcal{S}_1=\mathcal{S}_2$, and otherwise eliminating additive offsets originating solely from independent randomness.

implicit_assumptions.text: The system is governed by stagewise bounds from Section 17.2.4.
The claim relies on combining intermediate estimates.

steps.text: The inequality follows by combining the intermediate estimates with the unification lemma (17.2.4.3).

label: rem-context-5056
title: Feller-type (continuity-preserving) properties for $\Psi$ follow from the stagewise measurability and continuity assumptions stated in Section 2 for the operators and aggregators; on compact (or sublevel) sets these imply boundedness and continuity of the induced kernel maps.
nl_statement: Feller-type properties for $\Psi$ follow from stagewise measurability and continuity assumptions on the operators and aggregators, which imply boundedness and continuity of the induced kernel maps on compact or sublevel sets.

hypotheses.text: stagewise measurability and continuity assumptions stated in Section 2 for the operators and aggregators
